stream_context.summary: Kaze focused almost the entire stream on visual and technical work for the overworld’s ocean—selecting dock textures, designing a new vertex-driven wave system, and testing it in-game. At the start he also reported finishing a ground-up rewrite of Mario 64’s audio engine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze completed a near-total rewrite of the Mario 64 audio engine; it is now more memory-efficient, fully understood by him, and legally distinct except for the RSP interface.
development_findings.quote: I spent a lot of time completely rewriting Mario 64's audio engine … it's all my own code now. As long as we change the way we interface with the RSP as well, I think we're fine legally to just use this in our own game.

development_findings.summary: Today’s milestone was prototyping a new water system: hex-tessellated mesh, sine-wave vertex motion, inward-moving waves, distance-based amplitude, and per-vertex color tint to imply depth.
development_findings.quote: Now the waves actually look properly going into the island. It looks very tropical.

development_findings.summary: Performance budget is being watched; final water mesh reduced to ~600 visible triangles after culling, well under limits.
development_findings.quote: It's only 600 triangles, and I haven't even removed the invisible ones yet.

development_findings.summary: Future tasks: add foam near shores, disable wave deformation around Mario to avoid clipping, and prune invisible water triangles.
development_findings.quote: The next step would be … map the foam onto it and make the foam go into the island.

development_findings.summary: Overall game will stream seamlessly without loading zones; Kaze prefers the term "open zone" to "open world."
development_findings.quote: This is all just going to feel open world, and there's not going to be loading zones, but calling this an open world is maybe a little cringe.

development_findings.summary: Target cartridge size is 64 MB (end-of-life N64 spec); he is not limiting the project to the original 8 MB.
development_findings.quote: I'm not going with an 8 megabyte game, I'm going with 64 megabytes.

development_findings.summary: Early Mario 64 hacks were often not console-compatible due to poor tools; this project is being kept console-safe.
development_findings.quote: Most of my romhacks are not console compatible … This one is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is wary of YouTube comment noise and legal concerns but remains upbeat; he shows frustration at cheap visual solutions yet excitement when breakthroughs occur.
Personal life peek: his nine-month-old baby “loves eating the remote,” and he accidentally dropped from 215 lbs to ~194 lbs recently.
context_findings.quote: My baby's favorite thing … is eating the remote.

context_findings.summary: Work–life note: no stream on Easter; next likely on Monday or Tuesday.
Kaze drinks sparkling water, not energy drinks, and avoids them for health.
context_findings.quote: I would never drink an energy drink.

biobak.summary: Suggested depth-based vertex coloring for water and cautioned about wave/swim interactions; provided general feedback during shader discussion.
biobak.quote: We can do that Biobak, but what about swimming in it?

key_stories.title: Rewriting the Audio Engine
key_stories.summary: Over the prior week Kaze replaced Nintendo’s original audio routines with his own, achieving better memory usage and full code ownership.
key_stories.challenge: Nintendo’s audio engine was opaque, memory-hungry, and legally sensitive.
key_stories.process: Read, reverse-engineered, and rewrote each subsystem while retaining only the low-level RSP calls.
key_stories.outcome: Engine runs, is easier to debug, and positions the hack for possible stand-alone release.
key_stories.key_quote: Now I understand the whole codebase, meaning it's going to be very easy to debug any problems that may occur.

key_stories.title: Taming the Tropical Sea
key_stories.summary: On-stream Kaze iterated through multiple water prototypes—flat scrolling textures, Gerstner waves, dense meshes—before settling on a hex-tessellated sine system that looks good and runs fast.
key_stories.challenge: Needed convincing, direction-aware waves that wouldn’t break swimming or performance.
key_stories.process: Sketched math in Paint, tested triangle counts, wrote custom vertex shader logic, adjusted phase, amplitude, depth tint, and mesh density.
key_stories.outcome: Achieved visually pleasing inward-moving waves at ~600 tris; next steps are foam and Mario-safe zones.
key_stories.key_quote: It's kind of crazy how easy it is to make a map look good if you just have good shaders—or good fixed-function pipelines.

key_stories.title: Console Compatibility Realities
key_stories.summary: Chat questioned console support, leading Kaze to reflect on how older hacks often ignored hardware limits, whereas RtYI is being built with real N64 specs in mind.
key_stories.challenge: Reconciling community expectations for ‘real’ N64 hacks with modern development conveniences.
key_stories.process: Explained historical tool limitations and how the current decomp & toolchain allow true console builds.
key_stories.outcome: Project remains console-compatible but not restricted to tiny cartridge sizes.
key_stories.key_quote: For the longest time the Mario 64 community was such a pathetic part of the homebrew community.
